question: How do I apply to universities in Kent?
answer:
Most undergraduate courses in the UK require application through UCAS (Universities and Colleges Admissions Service). The process involves:
  1. Creating a UCAS account at ucas.com
  2. Selecting up to 5 courses
  3. Writing a personal statement
  4. Getting a reference (usually from a teacher or advisor)
  5. Paying the application fee (£22.50 for a single choice or £27 for multiple choices)

For postgraduate courses, you typically apply directly to the university through their website.

As a refugee, you may be eligible for application fee waivers. Contact the university's admissions office or refugee support team to inquire about this.

question: What are the application deadlines?
answer:
For undergraduate courses starting in September 2025:
  • 15 October 2024: Applications for medicine, dentistry, veterinary courses, and all courses at Oxford and Cambridge
  • 31 January 2025: Applications for most undergraduate courses
  • 30 June 2025: Final deadline for late applications

For postgraduate courses, deadlines vary by university and program. Some popular courses fill up quickly, so it's advisable to apply as early as possible.

For refugee scholarships, deadlines are often earlier than general admissions deadlines. Check specific scholarship pages for details.

question: What English language qualifications do I need?
answer:
Most universities require one of the following English language qualifications:
  • IELTS Academic: Usually 6.0-7.0 overall, with no component below 5.5-6.0
  • TOEFL iBT: Typically 80-100 overall
  • Pearson Test of English (PTE) Academic: Usually 50-65 overall
  • Cambridge English: Advanced (CAE): Grade C or above
  • Duolingo English Test: Some universities now accept this (typically 105-115)

Requirements vary by university and course, with higher requirements for language-intensive subjects like Law, Medicine, or English Literature.

Some universities offer pre-sessional English courses if you don't meet the requirements, allowing you to improve your English before starting your degree.

question: What financial support is available for refugees?
answer:
Refugees with settled status in the UK have several funding options:
  • Student Finance England: If you have refugee status or humanitarian protection, you can apply for tuition fee loans and maintenance loans
  • University Scholarships: Many universities offer specific scholarships for refugees
  • Charitable Organizations: Several charities provide grants for refugees in higher education
  • Hardship Funds: Universities have emergency funds for students facing financial difficulties

For asylum seekers whose claims are still being processed, options are more limited but include specific scholarships and bursaries from universities and charitable organizations.

Visit our Funding & Scholarships resource page for more detailed information.

question: How are international qualifications recognized in the UK?
answer:
UK universities assess international qualifications through:
  • UK ENIC (formerly NARIC): The official agency that compares international qualifications to UK standards
  • University Admissions Teams: Many universities have experience with qualifications from different countries
  • Foundation Year Programs: If your qualifications aren't directly equivalent, you might be offered a foundation year

Most universities list their international entry requirements on their websites, often organized by country. If your country isn't listed, contact the admissions team directly.

For a Statement of Comparability from UK ENIC, visit www.enic.org.uk. This service has a fee, but some universities will cover this cost for refugee applicants.

question: Do I need a student visa if I have refugee status?
answer:
No, if you have been granted refugee status in the UK, you do not need a student visa to study. Your refugee status gives you the right to study at any level of education.

However, you should provide the university with:

  • Your Biometric Residence Permit (BRP)
  • Home Office documentation confirming your status
  • Any other identity documents you have

If your refugee status is due to expire during your course, you should apply for an extension well in advance. Universities can often provide advice on this process.

question: What support services are available at universities?
answer:
Universities offer a range of support services for all students, including refugees:
  • Wellbeing and Mental Health Support: Counseling services, mental health advisors, and wellbeing workshops
  • Academic Support: Study skills workshops, writing centers, and personal tutors
  • Financial Advice: Budgeting help, hardship funds, and scholarship information
  • Careers Services: CV help, interview practice, and job search support
  • Disability Support: Accommodations and assistive technology for students with disabilities
  • International Student Support: Visa advice, cultural adjustment, and English language support

Many universities also have specific refugee support coordinators or teams who understand the unique challenges faced by refugee students.
